title-group.article-title: Temporal and spatial variations of PM2 and PM10 concentrations in Mongolia

institution-wrap.institution: National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES), Japan

abstract.p: PM2.5 and PM10 data for the 4 distinct sites of Mongolia from 2008 to 2020 is found …. …

sec.title: 1. 01_datawork
sec.p: Munkhtsetseg
Library

sec.title: 1.1 Import the dataset and remove the duplicates
sec.p: Import the dataset from the directory of: ~/Data Input/Preprocessing data/Preprocessing data.csv, assign the dataset as object of df:
Remove the duplicates with the function of distinct(), assign the dataset as df_01:

sec.title: 1.2 Produce a table with missing data
1.2.0.1 For date options as year, month, etc:
1.2.1 By percentages
sec.preformat: # A tibble: 4 × 6 # Groups: Station.name [4] Station.name missing_PM2 missing_PM10 missing_Vis missing_WS missing_WD <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> 1 Dalanzadgad 19.2 25.7 44.5 24.3 24.3 2 Sainshand 19.7 20.0 15.7 14.6 14.6 3 UB 11.0 11.9 4.53 4.85 4.85 4 Zamynuud 12.7 14.4 5.49 7.44 7.44

sec.title: 1.3 Note that:
sec.p: We use the data in the period of 2009-2018, which has been regarded as a monitoring work stabilized since 2008 when is the beginning of the monitoring. According to NIES, site maintenance was consistent up to 2018.
+Sainshand site, data 2009-2015 get used; + Dalanzad site: 2009-2016. + UB: 2009-2018 + Zamyn uud: 2009-2018

sec.title: 2. Remove the spikes, and produce an extended table
sec.p: Remove the spikes in the datasets, and produce the table with NA, with removed spikes; express it in a percentages. #| Comments*kedjkdjk ### Remove the spikes Method 1. Mean value +- (3-5)SD - Find Monthly mean #| flow: 1st - Remove spikes PMs >10 mgm/hour is unreasonable. #| - Exclude 0 values in PMs.
#| flow: 2nd - ratio check. PM10 >= PM2.5
#| flow: 2nd - ratio check. remove data of ratio>1
#| flow: 2nd - Method 1. Mean value +- (3-5)SD - Monthly mean at stations #| output: false
Option 1:
Option 2:
sec.preformat: # A tibble: 0 × 19 # ℹ 19 variables: Year <int>, Month <int>, Day <int>, Hour <int>, # correct_PM10 <dbl>, correct_PM2 <dbl>, Visibility <int>, WD <int>, # WS <dbl>, WS.u <dbl>, WS.v <dbl>, OPC <int>, Station.name <chr>, # Date <chr>, PM10 <dbl>, PM2 <dbl>, PM10_rel <dbl>, PM2_rel <dbl>, # ratio <dbl>

sec.title: 3.1 Fill the missing data
sec.p: Method 1. Fill the gap Method 2. Relationship equation Method 3. Look-up table

sec.title: 3.3 Introduction

caption.p: Figure 1: Timeline of recent earthquakes on La Palma

sec.p: Based on data up to and including 1971, eruptions on La Palma happen every 79.8 years on average.

Studies of the magma systems feeding the volcano, such as Marrero et al. (2019), have proposed that there are two main magma reservoirs feeding the Cumbre Vieja volcano; one in the mantle (30-40km depth) which charges and in turn feeds a shallower crustal reservoir (10-20km depth).
Eight eruptions have been recorded since the late 1400s (Figure 1).
Data and methods are discussed in Section 0.1.

Let x x denote the number of eruptions in a year. Then,
x x can be modeled by a Poisson distribution

where \lambda λ is the rate of eruptions per year. Using Equation 1, the probability of an eruption in the next
t t years can be calculated.

caption.p: Table 1: Recent historic eruptions on La Palma

sec.p: Table 1 summarises the eruptions recorded since the colonization of the islands by Europeans in the late 1400s.
La Palma is one of the west most islands in the Volcanic Archipelago of the Canary Islands (Figure 2).

caption.p: Figure 3: Locations of earthquakes on La Palma since 2017

sec.p: kk

element-citation.article-title: Strategies for the development of volcanic hazard maps in monogenetic volcanic fields: The example of La Palma (Canary Islands)

title-group.article-title: Temporal and spatial variations of PM2 and PM10 concentrations in Mongolia

institution-wrap.institution: National Institute for Environmental Studies (NIES), Japan

abstract.p: PM2.5 and PM10 data for the 4 distinct sites of Mongolia from 2008 to 2020 is found …. …

sec.title: 1. 01_datawork
sec.p: Munkhtsetseg
Library

sec.code: library(tidyverse)

sec.preformat: ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.4 ✔ forcats 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.5.1 ✔ ggplot2 3.4.4 ✔ tibble 3.2.1 ✔ lubridate 1.9.3 ✔ tidyr 1.3.0 ✔ purrr 1.0.2 ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

sec.title: 1.1 Import the dataset and remove the duplicates
sec.p: Import the dataset from the directory of: ~/Data Input/Preprocessing data/Preprocessing data.csv, assign the dataset as object of df:

sec.code: df <- read.csv("~/Data Input/Preprocessing data/Preprocessing data.csv")

sec.p: Remove the duplicates with the function of distinct(), assign the dataset as df_01:

sec.code: df_00 <- df |> distinct() |> rename(correct_PM10 = PM2, correct_PM2 = PM10) |> mutate(PM10=correct_PM10, PM2=correct_PM2, PM10_rel=PM10, PM2_rel=PM2, ratio = PM2/PM10)

sec.title: 1.2 Produce a table with missing data

sec.code:
df_000 <- df_00 |> filter(Year<2019 & Year >2008)
df_01 <- df_000 |> rowwise() |> filter((Year != 2019 & Station.name == "Zamynuud") | (Year < 2016 & Station.name == "Sainshand") | (Year < 2021 & Station.name == "UB") | (Year < 2017 & Station.name == "Dalanzadgad") ) head(df_01)

sec.title: 1.2.0.1 For date options as year, month, etc:

sec.code: Table_NA_by_Year <- df_01 |> group_by(Station.name,Year) |> summarise(NA_date = sum(!is.na(Date)), NA_PM2 = sum(is.na(PM2)), NA_PM10 = sum(is.na(PM10)), NA_Vis = sum(is.na(Visibility)), NA_WD = sum(is.na(WD)), NA_WS = sum(is.na(WS)), NA_OPC = sum(is.na(OPC)) )

sec.preformat: `summarise()` has grouped output by 'Station.name'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.

sec.code: Table_NA_by_Station <- df_01 |> group_by(Station.name) |> summarise(NA_date = sum(!is.na(Date)), NA_PM2 = sum(is.na(PM2)), NA_PM10 = sum(is.na(PM10)), NA_Vis = sum(is.na(Visibility)), NA_WD = sum(is.na(WD)), NA_WS = sum(is.na(WS)), NA_OPC = sum(is.na(OPC)) ) Table_NA_by_Station

sec.preformat: `summarise()` has grouped output by 'Station.name'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.

# A tibble: 4 × 6 # Groups: Station.name [4] Station.name missing_PM2 missing_PM10 missing_Vis missing_WS missing_WD <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> 1 Dalanzadgad 19.2 25.7 44.5 24.3 24.3 2 Sainshand 19.7 20.0 15.7 14.6 14.6 3 UB 11.0 11.9 4.53 4.85 4.85 4 Zamynuud 12.7 14.4 5.49 7.44 7.44

sec.title: 1.3 Note that:
sec.p: We use the data in the period of 2009-2018, which has been regarded as a monitoring work stabilized since 2008 when is the beginning of the monitoring. According to NIES, site maintenance was consistent up to 2018.
+Sainshand site, data 2009-2015 get used; + Dalanzad site: 2009-2016. + UB: 2009-2018 + Zamyn uud: 2009-2018

sec.title: 2. Remove the spikes, and produce an extended table
sec.p: Remove the spikes in the datasets, and produce the table with NA, with removed spikes; express it in a percentages. #| Comments*kedjkdjk ### Remove the spikes Method 1. Mean value +- (3-5)SD - Find Monthly mean #| flow: 1st - Remove spikes PMs >10 mgm/hour is unreasonable. #| - Exclude 0 values in PMs.

sec.preformat: Warning: Removed 39650 rows containing missing values (`position_stack()`).Warning: Removed 23168 rows containing missing values (`geom_line()`).

sec.p: #| flow: 2nd - ratio check. PM10 >= PM2.5

sec.code: df_01 |> filter(ratio >1) |> ggplot(aes(x=PM2, y=PM10, size=WS)) + geom_point() + facet_wrap(~Station.name)

sec.preformat: Warning: Removed 1002 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).

sec.p: #| flow: 2nd - ratio check. remove data of ratio>1

sec.code: df_01 <- df_01 |> filter(PM2<10 & PM10<10 & PM10 != 0 & PM2 != 0 & ratio < 1) head(df_01)

sec.preformat: Warning: Removed 8004 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).

sec.p: #| flow: 2nd - Method 1. Mean value +- (3-5)SD - Monthly mean at stations #| output: false
Option 1:

sec.code: df_02a <- df_01 |> group_by(Station.name, Month) |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> filter(PM2<10 & PM10<10) |> dplyr::mutate_at(vars(PM2, PM10), ~ ifelse(near(., mean(.), sd(.) * 3), ., "Outlier")) |> dplyr::filter_if(is.character, any_vars(. == "Outlier")) df_02a

sec.preformat: Warning: Removed 209 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).Warning: Removed 209 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).Warning: Removed 209 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).

sec.p: Option 2:

sec.code: df_02a1 <- df_01 |> group_by(Station.name, Month) |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> dplyr::mutate_at(vars(PM2, PM10), ~ ifelse(near(., mean(.), sd(.) * 3), ., mean(.))) df_02a1

df_02b <- df_01 |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> dplyr::mutate_at(vars(PM2, PM10), ~ ifelse(near(., mean(., .by = c(Station.name, Month)), sd(.) * 3), ., "Outlier")) |> dplyr::filter_if(is.character, any_vars(. == "Outlier")) df_02b

df_02b1 <- df_01 |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> dplyr::mutate_at(vars(PM2, PM10), ~ ifelse(near(., mean(., .by = c(Station.name, Month)), sd(.) * 3), ., mean(., .by =c(Station.name, Month)))) |> dplyr::filter_if(is.numeric, any_vars(. == mean(.))) df_02b1

sec.preformat: # A tibble: 0 × 19 # ℹ 19 variables: Year <int>, Month <int>, Day <int>, Hour <int>, # correct_PM10 <dbl>, correct_PM2 <dbl>, Visibility <int>, WD <int>, # WS <dbl>, WS.u <dbl>, WS.v <dbl>, OPC <int>, Station.name <chr>, # Date <chr>, PM10 <dbl>, PM2 <dbl>, PM10_rel <dbl>, PM2_rel <dbl>, # ratio <dbl>

sec.title: 3.1 Fill the missing data
sec.p: Method 1. Fill the gap Method 2. Relationship equation Method 3. Look-up table

sec.title: 3.3 Introduction

sec.code: eruptions <- c(1492, 1585, 1646, 1677, 1712, 1949, 1971, 2021) n_eruptions <- length(eruptions)
par(mar = c(3, 1, 1, 1) + 0.1) plot(eruptions, rep(0, n_eruptions), pch = "|", axes = FALSE) axis(1) box()

caption.p: Figure 1: Timeline of recent earthquakes on La Palma

sec.code: avg_years_between_eruptions <- mean(diff(eruptions[-n_eruptions])) avg_years_between_eruptions

sec.p: Based on data up to and including 1971, eruptions on La Palma happen every 79.8 years on average.

Studies of the magma systems feeding the volcano, such as Marrero et al. (2019), have proposed that there are two main magma reservoirs feeding the Cumbre Vieja volcano; one in the mantle (30-40km depth) which charges and in turn feeds a shallower crustal reservoir (10-20km depth).
Eight eruptions have been recorded since the late 1400s (Figure 1).
Data and methods are discussed in Section 0.1.

Let x x denote the number of eruptions in a year. Then,
x x can be modeled by a Poisson distribution

where \lambda λ is the rate of eruptions per year. Using Equation 1, the probability of an eruption in the next
t t years can be calculated.

caption.p: Table 1: Recent historic eruptions on La Palma

sec.p: Table 1 summarises the eruptions recorded since the colonization of the islands by Europeans in the late 1400s.
La Palma is one of the west most islands in the Volcanic Archipelago of the Canary Islands (Figure 2).

sec.code: la_palma |> ggplot(aes(Longitude, Latitude)) + geom_point(aes(color = Magnitude, size = 40-`Depth(km)`)) + scale_color_viridis_c(direction = -1) + scale_size(range = c(0.5, 2), guide = "none") + theme_bw()

caption.p: Figure 3: Locations of earthquakes on La Palma since 2017

sec.p: kk

sec.title: 4. Explore Earthquakes
sec.p: Munkhtsetseg
Library

sec.code: library(tidyverse)

sec.preformat: ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.4 ✔ forcats 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.5.1 ✔ ggplot2 3.4.4 ✔ tibble 3.2.1 ✔ lubridate 1.9.3 ✔ tidyr 1.3.0 ✔ purrr 1.0.2 ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

sec.title: 5. Import the dataset and remove the duplicates
sec.p: Import the dataset from the directory of: ~/Data Input/Preprocessing data/Preprocessing data.csv, assign the dataset as object of df:

sec.code: df <- read.csv("~/Data Input/Preprocessing data/Preprocessing data.csv")

sec.p: Remove the duplicates with the function of distinct(), assign the dataset as df_01:

sec.code: df_01 <- df %>% distinct()

sec.title: 5.1 Produce a table with missing data
sec.p: For date options as year, month, etc:

sec.code: Table_NA_by_Year <- df_01 %>% rowwise %>% group_by(Station.name,Year) %>% summarise(NA_date = sum(!is.na(Date)), NA_PM2 = sum(is.na(PM2)), NA_PM10 = sum(is.na(PM10)), NA_Vis = sum(is.na(Visibility)), NA_WD = sum(is.na(WD)), NA_WS = sum(is.na(WS)), NA_OPC = sum(is.na(OPC)) )

sec.preformat: `summarise()` has grouped output by 'Station.name'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.

sec.p: For station

sec.code: Table_NA_by_Station <- df_01 %>% rowwise %>% group_by(Station.name) %>% summarise(NA_date = sum(!is.na(Date)), NA_PM2 = sum(is.na(PM2)), NA_PM10 = sum(is.na(PM10)), NA_Vis = sum(is.na(Visibility)), NA_WD = sum(is.na(WD)), NA_WS = sum(is.na(WS)), NA_OPC = sum(is.na(OPC)) ) Table_NA_by_Station

sec.p: By percentages

sec.code: Table_NA_by_Station_percentage <- df_01 %>% rowwise %>% group_by(Station.name, Year) %>% summarise(NA_date = sum(!is.na(Date)), NA_PM2 = sum(is.na(PM2)), NA_PM10 = sum(is.na(PM10)), NA_Vis = sum(is.na(Visibility)), NA_WD = sum(is.na(WD)), NA_WS = sum(is.na(WS)), NA_OPC = sum(is.na(OPC)) ) %>% mutate( NA_PM2p = if_else(NA_date != NA_PM2, NA_PM2/NA_date*100, 0) ) %>% do({q <- .$NA_PM2*100/.$NA_date; sdq <- sd(q); attr(sdq, "data.all") <- q; data.frame(sdq)})

sec.preformat: `summarise()` has grouped output by 'Station.name'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.
# A tibble: 4 × 2 # Groups: Station.name [4] Station.name sdq <chr> <dbl> 1 Dalanzadgad 10.7 2 Sainshand 25.9 3 UB 17.9 4 Zamynuud 39.6

sec.p: Note that the echo = FALSE parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.

sec.title: 6. Remove the spikes, and produce an extended table
sec.p: Remove the spikes in the datasets, and produce the table with NA, with removed spikes; express it in a percentages.

sec.title: 6.0.1 Remove the spikes Method 1. Mean value +- (3-5)SD
sec.p: Method 2. Seasonal variations, and trend-mean

sec.title: 7.1 Fill the missing data
sec.p: Method 1. Fill the gap Method 2. Relationship equation Method 3. Look-up table

sec.code: library(tidyverse)

sec.p: Read a clean version of data:

sec.code: la_palma <- read_csv("la-palma.csv")

sec.preformat:
Rows: 11347 Columns: 5 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," dbl (4): Longitude, Latitude, Depth(km), Magnitude dttm (1): DateTime
ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

sec.p: Create spatial plot:

sec.code: la_palma |> ggplot(aes(Longitude, Latitude)) + geom_point(aes(color = Magnitude, size = 40-`Depth(km)`)) + scale_color_viridis_c(direction = -1) + scale_size(range = c(0.5, 2), guide = "none") + theme_bw()

caption.p: Figure 4: Locations of earthquakes on La Palma since 2017

sec.p: Figure 4 shows the location of recent Earthquakes on La Palma.

sec.code: Table_NA_by_Year <- df_01 %>% rowwise %>% group_by(Station.name,Year) %>% summarise(NA_date = sum(!is.na(Date)), NA_PM2 = sum(is.na(PM2)), NA_PM10 = sum(is.na(PM10)), NA_Vis = sum(is.na(Visibility)), NA_WD = sum(is.na(WD)), NA_WS = sum(is.na(WS)), NA_OPC = sum(is.na(OPC)) )

sec.title: Import the dataset and remove the duplicates
sec.p: Import the dataset from the directory of: ~/Data Input/Preprocessing data/Preprocessing data.csv, assign the dataset as object of df:

sec.code: df <- read.csv("~/Data Input/Preprocessing data/Preprocessing data.csv")

sec.p: Remove the duplicates with the function of distinct(), assign the dataset as df_01:

sec.code: df_00 <- df |> distinct() |> rename(correct_PM10 = PM2, correct_PM2 = PM10) |> mutate(PM10=correct_PM10, PM2=correct_PM2, PM10_rel=PM10, PM2_rel=PM2, ratio = PM2/PM10)

sec.title: Produce a table with missing data

sec.code:
df_000 <- df_00 |> filter(Year<2019 & Year >2008)
df_01 <- df_000 |> rowwise() |> filter((Year != 2019 & Station.name == "Zamynuud") | (Year < 2016 & Station.name == "Sainshand") | (Year < 2021 & Station.name == "UB") | (Year < 2017 & Station.name == "Dalanzadgad") ) head(df_01)

sec.title: For date options as year, month, etc:

sec.code: Table_NA_by_Year <- df_01 |> group_by(Station.name,Year) |> summarise(NA_date = sum(!is.na(Date)), NA_PM2 = sum(is.na(PM2)), NA_PM10 = sum(is.na(PM10)), NA_Vis = sum(is.na(Visibility)), NA_WD = sum(is.na(WD)), NA_WS = sum(is.na(WS)), NA_OPC = sum(is.na(OPC)) )
Table_NA_by_Year

sec.preformat: `summarise()` has grouped output by 'Station.name'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.

sec.code: Table_NA_by_Station <- df_01 |> group_by(Station.name) |> summarise(NA_date = sum(!is.na(Date)), NA_PM2 = sum(is.na(PM2)), NA_PM10 = sum(is.na(PM10)), NA_Vis = sum(is.na(Visibility)), NA_WD = sum(is.na(WD)), NA_WS = sum(is.na(WS)), NA_OPC = sum(is.na(OPC)) ) Table_NA_by_Station
Table_NA_by_Station_percentage

sec.preformat: `summarise()` has grouped output by 'Station.name'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.

# A tibble: 4 × 6 # Groups: Station.name [4] Station.name missing_PM2 missing_PM10 missing_Vis missing_WS missing_WD <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> 1 Dalanzadgad 19.2 25.7 44.5 24.3 24.3 2 Sainshand 19.7 20.0 15.7 14.6 14.6 3 UB 11.0 11.9 4.53 4.85 4.85 4 Zamynuud 12.7 14.4 5.49 7.44 7.44

sec.title: Note that:
sec.p: We use the data in the period of 2009-2018, which has been regarded as a monitoring work stabilized since 2008 when is the beginning of the monitoring. According to NIES, site maintenance was consistent up to 2018.
+Sainshand site, data 2009-2015 get used; + Dalanzad site: 2009-2016. + UB: 2009-2018 + Zamyn uud: 2009-2018

sec.title: Remove the spikes, and produce an extended table
sec.p: Remove the spikes in the datasets, and produce the table with NA, with removed spikes; express it in a percentages. #| Comments*kedjkdjk ### Remove the spikes Method 1. Mean value +- (3-5)SD - Find Monthly mean #| flow: 1st - Remove spikes PMs >10 mgm/hour is unreasonable. #| - Exclude 0 values in PMs.

sec.code: ggplot(df_01)+ geom_line(aes(x = Date, y = PM2 ))+ geom_col(aes(x = Date, y =PM10 )) + facet_wrap(~Station.name)

sec.preformat: Warning: Removed 39650 rows containing missing values (`position_stack()`).
Warning: Removed 23168 rows containing missing values (`geom_line()`).

sec.p: #| flow: 2nd - ratio check. PM10 >= PM2.5

sec.code: df_01 |> filter(ratio >1) |> ggplot(aes(x=PM2, y=PM10, size=WS)) + geom_point() + facet_wrap(~Station.name)

sec.preformat: Warning: Removed 1002 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).

sec.p: #| flow: 2nd - ratio check. remove data of ratio>1

sec.code: df_01 <- df_01 |> filter(PM2<10 & PM10<10 & PM10 != 0 & PM2 != 0 & ratio < 1) head(df_01)
df_01 |> ggplot(aes(x=PM2, y=PM10, size=WS)) + geom_point() + facet_wrap(~Station.name)

sec.preformat: Warning: Removed 8004 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).

sec.p: #| flow: 2nd - Method 1. Mean value +- (3-5)SD - Monthly mean at stations #| output: false
Option 1:

sec.code: df_02a <- df_01 |> group_by(Station.name, Month) |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> filter(PM2<10 & PM10<10) |> dplyr::mutate_at(vars(PM2, PM10), ~ ifelse(near(., mean(.), sd(.) * 3), ., "Outlier")) |> dplyr::filter_if(is.character, any_vars(. == "Outlier")) df_02a
ggplot(df_02a, aes(x=Date, y=PM10_rel, color = Visibility, size=WS)) + geom_point() + facet_wrap(~Station.name)
ggplot(df_02a, aes(x=Date, y=PM2_rel, color = Visibility, size=WS)) + geom_point() + facet_wrap(~Station.name)
ggplot(df_02a, aes(x=Date, y=ratio, color = Visibility, size=WS)) + geom_point() + facet_wrap(~Station.name)

sec.preformat: Warning: Removed 209 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).
Warning: Removed 209 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).
Warning: Removed 209 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).

sec.p: Option 2:

sec.code: df_02a1 <- df_01 |> group_by(Station.name, Month) |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> dplyr::mutate_at(vars(PM2, PM10), ~ ifelse(near(., mean(.), sd(.) * 3), ., mean(.))) df_02a1

df_02b <- df_01 |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> dplyr::mutate_at(vars(PM2, PM10), ~ ifelse(near(., mean(., .by = c(Station.name, Month)), sd(.) * 3), ., "Outlier")) |> dplyr::filter_if(is.character, any_vars(. == "Outlier")) df_02b

df_02b1 <- df_01 |> drop_na(PM2, PM10) |> dplyr::mutate_at(vars(PM2, PM10), ~ ifelse(near(., mean(., .by = c(Station.name, Month)), sd(.) * 3), ., mean(., .by =c(Station.name, Month)))) |> dplyr::filter_if(is.numeric, any_vars(. == mean(.))) df_02b1

sec.preformat: # A tibble: 0 × 19 # ℹ 19 variables: Year <int>, Month <int>, Day <int>, Hour <int>, # correct_PM10 <dbl>, correct_PM2 <dbl>, Visibility <int>, WD <int>, # WS <dbl>, WS.u <dbl>, WS.v <dbl>, OPC <int>, Station.name <chr>, # Date <chr>, PM10 <dbl>, PM2 <dbl>, PM10_rel <dbl>, PM2_rel <dbl>, # ratio <dbl>

sec.title: Fill the missing data
sec.p: Method 1. Fill the gap Method 2. Relationship equation Method 3. Look-up table
